item.title: France and Britain Say Sarin Likely Used in Syria
item.description: The findings, based on laboratory tests of samples removed from Syria, emerged as officials met in Geneva to try to set up international peace talks.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By STEVEN ERLANGER, NICK CUMMING-BRUCE and ALAN COWELL
item.media:description: Foreign Minister Laurent Fabius of France said laboratory tests had confirmed the use of sarin in the civil war in Syria.

item.title: India Ink: Death of Victim Focuses Attention on Acid Attacks
item.description: Preeti Rathi, 23, succumbed to her injuries from an acid attack on Saturday.
item.dc:creator: By MALAVIKA VYAWAHARE
item.media:description: A demonstration outside Maharashtra Home Minister R. R. Patil's house in Mumbai demanding justice for the victims of acid attacks, on June 2.

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: Can Job Training Trump a Degree?
item.description: While Chinese and Indian university graduates are struggling to find jobs, those coming out of vocational schools as skilled mechanics, technicians and hotel workers are having better luck.
item.dc:creator: By JOYCE LAU
item.media:credit: Prashanth Vishwanathan for the International Herald Tribune
item.media:description: Inderjeet Singh got individual attention from a teacher at a Gras Academy school.

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: In Hong Kong, a Rain-Soaked Celebration of Democracy
item.description: Tens of thousands of people took part in a democracy rally in Hong Kong to mark the crushing of the June 4, 1989, demonstrations in Beijing, lashed by heavy rain.
item.dc:creator: By DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW
item.media:description: Protesters in Hong Kong yesterday, in front a backdrop showing Beijing's Tiananmen Square as it was in June 1989.

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: IHT Quick Read: June 5
item.description: France says Syrian government used nerve gas; migrant detention centers in Europe criticized; diabetes cases rising in Vietnam; Bloomberg starts a venture capital fund; and a composer “plays” the Eiffel Tower.
item.dc:creator: By THE INTERNATIONAL HERALD TRIBUNE
item.media:description: Authorities say the detention centers are essential to better regulate illegal immigration and that they comply with European Union guidelines.

item.title: China Allows Return of U.S. Executive Before Xi’s Visit
item.description: The release of the engineer suggests China may be seeking to start a summit between President Xi Jinping and President Obama on a positive note.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW JACOBS

item.title: A Panoramic View of Taksim Square
Italy's Migrant Detention Centers Are Cruel, Rights Groups Say
item.description: Centers used to hold illegal immigrants in Italy and elsewhere in Europe are coming in for criticism from rights groups that say they are inhumane, ineffective and costly.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By ELISABETTA POVOLEDO
item.media:description: Authorities say the detention centers are essential to better regulate illegal immigration and that they comply with European Union guidelines.

item.title: Tepco Says Water at Fukushima Is Contaminated
item.description: Tokyo Electric Power Company, which had previously said that there were no radioactive particles, indicated that some had been found in water flowing into the plant.
item.dc:creator: By MARTIN FACKLER

item.title: U.S.-China Meeting’s Aim: Personal Diplomacy
item.description: The visit between President Obama and President Xi Jinping of China is less scripted than such visits usually are, including time for dinner and strolls on the California estate where they will meet.
item.dc:creator: By MARK LANDLER and JACKIE CALMES
item.media:description: Sunnylands Center, part of the 200-acre Annenberg Retreat.

item.title: Istanbul Protests Started Over Trees
item.description: The government’s plans to convert the park in Taksim Square into a mall designed like a replica Ottoman-era army barracks and subsequent protests have exposed a fault line in Turkey.
item.dc:creator: By TIM ARANGO
item.media:credit: Ed Ou for The New York Times
item.media:description: Protesters in Taksim Square in Istanbul on Tuesday.

item.title: London Journal: House of Lords Debates Gay-Marriage Bill
item.description: Time generally marches slowly in the House of Lords, but on the issue of gay rights, it has sped up considerably.
item.category: Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships
item.dc:creator: By SARAH LYALL
item.media:description: Same-sex marriage proponents held a vigil Tuesday outside the houses of Parliament in London.

item.title: China’s First Lady Won’t See U.S. Counterpart on Visit
item.description: Michelle Obama will remain in Washington when President Xi Jinping of China comes to California this weekend.
item.dc:creator: By JACKIE CALMES and JANE PERLEZ

item.title: France Offers Evidence of ‘Multiple’ Uses of Nerve Gas in Syria
item.description: The French foreign minister said tests confirmed that sarin gas had been used, and that there was “no doubt it was the regime.”
item.dc:creator: By STEVEN ERLANGER and NICK CUMMING-BRUCE
item.media:description: Foreign Minister Laurent Fabius of France said laboratory tests had confirmed the use of sarin in the civil war in Syria.

item.title: At War Blog: A Hunt for a Deadly Sniper From Two Perspectives
item.description: A corporal and a filmmaker recount their weeklong attempt to flush out a sniper during the 2010 assault on Marja in Helmand Province, Afghanistan.
item.dc:creator: By THOMAS GIBBONS-NEFF and BEN ANDERSON
item.media:description: Marines patrolling outside Marja in Afghanistan's Helmand Province in February 2010.

item.title: Diabetes Is the Price Vietnam Pays for Progress
item.description: The precise reasons for a spike in diabetes cases are hard to pin down – people are living longer, for one — but doctors say the prime culprits are “Westernization and urbanization.”
item.dc:creator: By THOMAS FULLER
item.media:credit: Justin Mott for the International Herald Tribune
item.media:description: Phu Thi Hong Thuy, a 48-year-old diabetic, had to have her leg amputated after she cut herself on a closet at home. “Sometimes I feel my leg itching — but when I look, it’s not there,” she said.

item.title: Japanese Pilots Worry About Repaired Boeing 787 Jets
item.description: Pilots were dismayed that Boeing did not improve cockpit displays to provide more substantial alerts if the batteries overheated.
item.dc:creator: By HIROKO TABUCHI and CHRISTOPHER DREW
item.media:description: An All Nippon Airways worker checked the door of a battery room on a repaired Boeing 787 Dreamliner last week.

item.title: Syrian Rebels Attempt Shift From Guerrilla Tactics
item.description: The rebels have been pulled between the limits of a lightly equipped guerrilla force and their urge to fight with the battlefield weight of an army.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By C. J. CHIVERS
item.media:description: Fighters with Ahfad al-Rasul, or the Grandsons of the Prophet, loaded ammunition into magazines at a base in Iblil, Syria.

item.title: Chinese Poultry Factory Was Considered a Model
item.description: The glowing assessments of the plant where more than 100 people were killed in a fiery explosion suggested government officials had missed problems.
item.dc:creator: By EDWARD WONG
item.media:description: A victim of a fire at a poultry processing plant in northeast China received treatment on Tuesday.

item.title: The Lede: Chants Against Iran’s Supreme Leader Heard in Video of Dissident Cleric’s Funeral
item.description: Chants in support of jailed opposition leaders, and against Iran’s ruling cleric, rang out during a funeral procession for a dissident religious leader in the city of Isfahan on Tuesday.
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY
item.media:description: A screenshot from the Web site of the Iranian Students' News Agency showing the coffin of Ayatollah Jalaledin Taheri, a dissident cleric who was buried in the city of Isfahan on Tuesday.

item.title: Memo From Latin America: Woman Who Sought Abortion in El Salvador Delivers Baby
item.description: The case of a sick woman in El Salvador who had been denied an abortion has convulsed the region, which is known for having some of the world’s most stringent abortion laws.
item.dc:creator: By KARLA ZABLUDOVSKY

item.title: Lei Jun Builds His Xiaomi Empire by Aping Apple and Steve Jobs
item.description: Led by Lei Jun, Xiaomi sold $2 billion in handsets in China last year, and he has carefully cultivated an image in the Steve Jobs mold.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID BARBOZA
item.media:description: Lei Jun, the Steve Jobs-mimicking chief of Xiaomi, introduced a new smartphone last summer in Beijing.

item.title: Xi Makes Bridge-Building Trip to Mexico
item.description: President Xi Jinping’s three-day visit was intended to smooth ties between Mexico and China, which have been rivals in exports to the United States.
item.dc:creator: By ELISABETH MALKIN

item.title: U.S. Military Deaths in Afghanistan
item.description: The Department of Defense has identified 2,214 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: In Egypt, Foreign Nonprofit Workers Convicted
item.description: The guilty verdict for more than three dozen employees, among them many Americans, came in a trial the United States has called politically motivated.
item.dc:creator: By BEN HUBBARD
